titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Evgeniia Sergeevna Isaenko Papers

change.item: April 21, 2014: Copied information from the Hoover website. March 25, 2011: revised to update encoding and add unitid by Elizabeth Phillips March 23, 2004: PUBLIC "-//Stanford University::Hoover Institution Archives//TEXT (US::CSt-H::::Evgeniia Sergeevna Isaenko Papers)//EN" "isaenko.xml" converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.cdl.xsl (2004-09-16).

did.abstract: Writings, correspondence, printed matter, and photographs, relating to Russian literature and to Russian émigré affairs. Includes some papers of Aleksei Leonidovich Isaenko, husband of Evgeniia Isaenko.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Boxes 12-15 not microfilmed, originals at the Museum of Russian Culture, San Francisco.

The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Evgeniia Sergeevna Isaenko Papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

altformavail.head: Location of Originals
altformavail.p: In part, originals in: Museum of Russian Culture, San Francisco.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: E. S. Isaenko was born Evgeniia Pechatkina in Askhabad on 16 December 1899, the daughter of General Sergei Pechatkin. Living in Harbin following the Revolution, she was among the first Russian students to depart for the United States in the early 1920s, where she continued her education at Pomona College. For personal reasons, she left college and went to San Francisco, making her living performing menial labor as a packer in a factory, dishwasher, seamstress, etc. Meanwhile, she devoted her free time to Russian social life, actively participating in musical, theatrical and literary presentations. She directed and acted in plays, and wrote articles, reviews, short stories and two books, Perekati-Pole (published in 1953) and Petr Ivanovich (1961).

Though she married Aleksei Leonidovich Isaenko and assumed his last name, she continued to publish under her maiden name. Her husband was also active in the San Francisco Russian community as librarian of the Russian Club and Russian Center. He was born in Orenburg in 1894, the son of Major General Leonid Isaenko. Receiving a degree in law from Moscow University in 1917, he joined the White Army in Siberia during the Civil War. He arrived in America in 1923, and met Evgeniia Sergeevna through their common interest in theatrical and social activities. He died in 1957; Evgeniia Sergeevna Isaenko died in Burlingame, California, in July 1969.

chronitem.event: Studied at Pomona College, Claremont, California

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the papers of Evgeniia Sergeevna Isaenko, an émigré writer and poet, author of the novel Perekati-Pole, published, as were many of her works, under her maiden name Evgeniia Pechatkina (she appears also to have published under the initials E. P., as well as under the pseudonyms E. Sergeeva and Maksim Davydov). Isaenko was an active figure in the Russian émigré community, staging plays and taking part in other social events, particularly those related to the Russian Center.
The collection also contains biographical materials relating to and correspondence of her husband, Aleksei Leonidovich Isaenko, a former army officer and director of the Russian Center library.

Detailed processing and preservation microfilming of these materials were made possible by a generous grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities and by matching funds from the Hoover Institution and the Museum of Russian Culture. The grant also provides depositing a microfilm copy in the Hoover Institution Archives. The original materials remain at the Museum of Russian Culture, San Francisco, as its property. A transfer table of corresponding box and reel numbers is available at the Hoover Institution Archives.

The Hoover Institution assumes all responsibility for notifying users that they must comply with the copyright law of the United States (Title 17 United States Code) and Hoover Rules for the Use and Reproduction of Archival Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Autobiographical note, clipping, identity papers, scrapbooks and other materials arranged alphabetically by physical form. Includes biographical materials of family members

did.unittitle: Correspondence with first wife, Mariia Isaenko,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes photograph, 1923, and certificate of naturalization, 1929

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes death notices and related materials. Also includes letter from N. Lapenson to N. A. Slobodchikov, 1971, forwarding these materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sympathy cards and letters on death of, 1947

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence of A. L. Isaenko. Arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent

did.unittitle: Consolidated Committee of the Russian National Organizations,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes related third-party correspondence to and from B. K. Grachev and N. N. Gracheva, c. 1934

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes clippings and letter from Witold Izdebsky

did.unittitle: Kirchev, N. S. and Kircheva, P. M.,
San Francisco Committee for the Aid of Russian Disabled Veterans Outside of Russia, Inc.,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copies of letters to the editor of Russkaia zhizn'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Short stories, novellas, poetry, newspaper articles, arranged chronologically by title

did.unittitle: Addresses in honor of various individuals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Include inserts. Mainly holograph drafts of works, but also include entries of a diary nature

did.unittitle: Reviews of plays, lectures, literary-musical evenings and similar events,
"Iavliautsia li Mertvyia dushi Gogolia anafemoi ili apofeozom Rossii?"
"Otviet na zashchitu 'Priznanie Patriarkha' B. S. Glagolina,"
"Pamiati stareishago chlena organizatsii 'ART' G. A. Kalinina,"
Review of Boris Gerasimov-Sherwood, Dva tigra,
Review of Victor Petrov, Saga Fort Ross,
Reviews of various issues of the periodical Sovremennik,
Speech in honor of unidentified individual,
Untitled article honoring Russkaia zhizn' on the occasion of its 15 th year of publication,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typescript and printed copy. Includes entire issue #1 of Rampa, edited by Isaenko

did.unittitle: Speech at a banquet in honor of S. A. Zharov,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes receipts and ledger. May also include financial records for sales of Petr Ivanovich

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes blurb and other prepublication materials, lists of booksellers, and advertisements

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plays and sketches by V. Mort, N. Narokov, A. Zhernakova, and others, staged by Isaenko or with her participation. May contain plays written by Isaenko. Arranged alphabetically by name of author

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes fragments, sketches adapted from other works, monologues, individual roles, notes for actors

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clippings, correspondence, writings, posters, scrapbook and other matter, arranged alphabetically by heading

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials relating to a literary-musical fundraiser for the benefit of Radio Liberty, San Francisco, 1968

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Albums, loose prints and negatives, arranged by subject

did.unittitle: 34 prints of E. S. and A. L. Isaenko, together, separately, and in groups
5 prints of the Russian Club, San Francisco,
120 prints of unidentified and miscellaneous individuals, groups, events, and places

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Primarily family and vacation photographs. Include depictions of flood in Harbin, China, 1920s

did.unittitle: One oversize photograph of unidentified actor in makeup

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials acquired after the microfilming of the Museum of Russian Culture, San Francisco collection
